natural problem: Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7.
natural solution: We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.
67 is prime, but 77 (7 times 11) is not. 87 has a units sum of 15 which is divisible by 3, so 87 itself is divisible by 3 and thus is not prime. 97 and 107 are prime.

By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> prime n = (if is_prime n \<and> n mod 10 = 7 then n else 0)"
shows  "sum prime {1..7} = 379"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.
 67 is prime, but 77 (7 times 11) is not. 87 has a units sum of 15 which is divisible by 3, so 87 itself is divisible by 3 and thus is not prime. 97 and 107 are prime.
 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> prime n = (if is_prime n \<and> n mod 10 = 7 then n else 0)"
shows  "sum prime {1..7} = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of all prime numbers less than or equal to 7 that end in 7. The final answer is 379.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes primes :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "primes = {p. prime p \<and> p mod 10 = 7}"
and h1 : "finite primes"
and h2 : "card primes = 7"
shows  "sum id primes = 379"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.

 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes primes :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "primes = {p. prime p \<and> p mod 10 = 7}"
and h1 : "finite primes"
and h2 : "card primes = 7"
shows  "sum id primes = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the sum of the seven prime numbers that end in 7. The final answer is 379.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = (nth_prime n) mod 10 = 7"
and h1 : "sum f {1..7} = 379"
shows  "sum f {1..7} = 379"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.

 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = (nth_prime n) mod 10 = 7"
and h1 : "sum f {1..7} = 379"
shows  "sum f {1..7} = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Assume we have a function $f(n)$ which is defined as the last digit (in base 10) of the $n$-th prime number, where this last digit is always 7. If the sum of $f(n)$ for $n$ from 1 to 7 is 379, prove that this sum is indeed 379.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. is_prime (p n) \<and> (p n mod 10 = 7)"
and h1 : "sum p {0..6} = 379"
shows  "sum p {0..6} = 379"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.
 67 is prime, but 77 (7 times 11) is not. 87 has a units sum of 15 which is divisible by 3, so 87 itself is divisible by 3 and thus is not prime. 97 and 107 are prime.
 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. is_prime (p n) \<and> (p n mod 10 = 7)"
and h1 : "sum p {0..6} = 379"
shows  "sum p {0..6} = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Let $p(n)$ denote the $n$-th prime number that ends with 7. If the sum of the first seven such prime numbers is 379, verify that the sum is indeed 379.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> prime n is_prime"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> (prime n mod 10) = 7"
and h2 : "sum prime {1..7} = 379"
shows  "sum prime {1..7} = 379"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.
 67 is prime, but 77 (7 times 11) is not. 87 has a units sum of 15 which is divisible by 3, so 87 itself is divisible by 3 and thus is not prime. 97 and 107 are prime.
 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> prime n is_prime"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> (prime n mod 10) = 7"
and h2 : "sum prime {1..7} = 379"
shows  "sum prime {1..7} = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider a function "prime" that maps natural numbers to natural numbers. For every natural number n greater than or equal to 1, prime(n) is a prime number and prime(n) mod 10 equals 7. If the sum of prime(n) for n from 1 to 7 equals 379, confirm that this sum is indeed 379.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: nat and primes :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length primes = 7"
and h1 : "list_all is_prime_nat primes"
and h2 : "list_all (\<lambda>n. n mod 10 = 7) primes"
shows  "sum_list primes = 379"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.
 67 is prime, but 77 (7 times 11) is not. 87 has a units sum of 15 which is divisible by 3, so 87 itself is divisible by 3 and thus is not prime. 97 and 107 are prime.
 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes sum :: nat and primes :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length primes = 7"
and h1 : "list_all is_prime_nat primes"
and h2 : "list_all (\<lambda>n. n mod 10 = 7) primes"
shows  "sum_list primes = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the sum of seven prime numbers, each ending with the digit 7. The final answer is 379.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes primes :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length primes = 7"
and h1 : "\<forall>p \<in> set primes. is_prime p \<and> (p mod 10) = 7"
shows  "sum_list primes = 379"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.
 67 is prime, but 77 (7 times 11) is not. 87 has a units sum of 15 which is divisible by 3, so 87 itself is divisible by 3 and thus is not prime. 97 and 107 are prime.
 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes primes :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length primes = 7"
and h1 : "\<forall>p \<in> set primes. is_prime p \<and> (p mod 10) = 7"
shows  "sum_list primes = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a list of 7 prime numbers, each ending in 7, find the sum of all the numbers in the list. The sum is 379.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. prime i is prime number"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. prime i mod 10 = 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. i \<le> 7"
shows  "sum prime {1..7} = 379"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.
 67 is prime, but 77 (7 times 11) is not. 87 has a units sum of 15 which is divisible by 3, so 87 itself is divisible by 3 and thus is not prime. 97 and 107 are prime.
 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. prime i is prime number"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. prime i mod 10 = 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. i \<le> 7"
shows  "sum prime {1..7} = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the sum of the first 7 prime numbers that end with 7. The final answer is 379.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and sum :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n is prime"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime n mod 10 = 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. sum n = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..n}. prime i)"
shows  "sum 7 = 379"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.
 67 is prime, but 77 (7 times 11) is not. 87 has a units sum of 15 which is divisible by 3, so 87 itself is divisible by 3 and thus is not prime. 97 and 107 are prime.
 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
and sum :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n is prime"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. prime n mod 10 = 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. sum n = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..n}. prime i)"
shows  "sum 7 = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that each $n$th prime number is a prime number that ends with 7, find the sum of the first 7 prime numbers that end with 7. The sum is 379.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes primes :: "nat list" and sum :: nat
assumes h0 : "primes = filter is_prime [n\<leftarrow>[1..], n mod 10 = 7]"
and h1 : "length primes = 7"
and h2 : "sum = listsum primes"
shows  "sum = 379"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that have a units digit of 7. The final Answer is 379
 ### Proof
 We write out the first few numbers with a units digit of 7: \[7, 17, 27, 37, 47, 57, 67, 77, 87, 97, 107, 117\] Note how 7 and 17 are prime, but 27 (9 times 3) is not. 37 and 47 are prime, but 57 (3 times 19) is not.

 By now, we have found our desired first seven prime numbers. Their sum is  \begin{align} 7 &+ 17 + 37 + 47 + 67 + 97 + 107 \\ &= 7+7+7+7+7+7+7 + 10 + 30 + 40 + 60 + 90 + 100 \\ &= 7(7) + 10(1+3+4+6+9+10) \\
 &= 49 + 10(33)=\boxed{379}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes primes :: "nat list" and sum :: nat
assumes h0 : "primes = filter is_prime [n\<leftarrow>[1..], n mod 10 = 7]"
and h1 : "length primes = 7"
and h2 : "sum = listsum primes"
shows  "sum = 379"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the sum of the first seven prime numbers that end with 7. The final answer is 379.
